instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.PP5V_S5: What is PP5V_S5? This is a 5v power rail that is present when the machine is in an S5 soft off state..
definitions.PP3V3_S5: What is PP3V3_S5? PP3V3_S5 is a 3.3v power rail when the system is in an S5 soft off power state.
definitions.PP5V_S0: What is PP5V_S0? PP5V_S0 is a 5v power rail present when the system is in an S0 working state..
definitions.PP5V_S3: What is PP5V_S3? PP5V_S3 is a 5v power rail present when the system is in an S3 suspend to RAM state..
definitions.PP3V3_S0: What is PP3V3_S0? The "PP3V3_S0" rail in a MacBook logic board is a power rail that supplies 3.3 volts to the system when it is fully awake (S0 state). .
definitions.U7000: What is U7000? U7000 refers to the ISL6258 or ISL6259 charging IC on Macbooks from 2008-2012.
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .

threads.title: 820 3330 <SIGNAL>PP5V_S5</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
820 3330 <SIGNAL>PP5V_S5</SIGNAL> voltage decimal jumps 3.697-36.97v, and I get a lightning bolt in my fluke. No water damage, is this an SMC issuse...

Diode mode readings
<SIGNAL>PP5V_S5</SIGNAL> .432V
<SIGNAL>PP5V_S3</SIGNAL> .400V
<SIGNAL>PP5V_S0</SIGNAL> .401V

<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL> .140V 
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S3</SIGNAL> .343V
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S0</SIGNAL> .293V

threads.title: 820 3330 <SIGNAL>PP5V_S5</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
Just to be clear, are you saying your 5V rail jumps between 3.7V and 37V?

Resistance in Ohm between <SIGNAL>PPVIN_S5_HS_OTHER_ISNS</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>PP5V_S5</SIGNAL>?

threads.title: 820 3330 <SIGNAL>PP5V_S5</SIGNAL>
threads.message: Yes, the decimal jumps back and forth making it 3.7 then 37v. Every time I retest voltage on that line, it changes it might say 4.2v and the decimal will once again jump back and forth from 4.2v to 42v, or 2.7v and 27v, so on and so forth.

threads.title: 820 3330 <SIGNAL>PP5V_S5</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
This is absolutely impossible. First the basics....
Green light present? PPBUS voltage? <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL>?

threads.title: 820 3330 <SIGNAL>PP5V_S5</SIGNAL>
threads.message: Duke looks like i made a rookie mistake, <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> read 12.59v, when I first tested it, so I moved on. Tested it again today and if I hold the probe there for a few sec it power cycling for 12.59v, 10.5v, 11.5v, back to 12 again. Line is not short, I changed <CHIP>U7000</CHIP> still power cycling...
